div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
SULTAN AND POWERS.
Rejection of note.
div.p: The Porte has rejected the proposals of the Powers regarding the financial control of Macedonia. (Reuter)
The reply of the Porte declines the Note of the Powers. It only grants the extension for two years of the mandate of the civil agents in Macedonia. (Havas)

div.head: AN IRRESISTIBLE TORRENT.
AGRARIAN RISINGS IN RUSSIA
div.p: The newspaper, of the Volga provinces are filled with descriptions of agrarian risings which they describe as an irresistible torrent. Landowners, stewards, and police have been thrown into improvised prisons and the pea sants are traversing the country with red flags, pillaging and burning. (Reuter)

div.head: KING OF PORTUGAL IN PARIS.
WELCOMED BY M. LOUBET.
div.p: The King of Portugal has arrived. He was welcomed by President Loubet and the Min- isters. (Reuter)
The King of Portugal has arrived. Cordial toasts were exchanged at the banquet at the Elise. (Havas)

div.head: KING HAKON’S STATE ENTRY.
KING EDWARD’S REPRESENTATIVE.
div.p: Colonel Henry Knollys will represent the King at the State entry of King Hakon into Christiania. (Reuter)

div.head: THE KING.
SPENDS DAY SHOOTING.
div.p: The King took part in Lord Farquhar’s hooting party today, using a light phaeton. (Reuter)

div.head: GORDON COLLEGE.
NEW MEMBERS OF COUNCIL.
div.p: It has been decided by a meeting of the Council of Gordon College, held here, to authorise the addition of three ordinary mem- bers Mr. Wellcome, Sir William Mather, and Sir Henry Craik were appointed. (Reuter)

div.head: COOK’S EGYPT AND SUDAN.
div.p: The new handbook to Egypt and the Sudan, which Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son have just issued, is bound to be recognised as the stan- dard guide book to the valley of the Nile. This new handbook has been entreated to the hands of Dr. Wallis Badge, the well known savant, who is in charge of the Egyptian and Assyrian antiquities in the British Museum. The new guide is a great improvement on the former handbook, the greater part of it having been re-written and voluminous fresh information added Foil particulars are given as to Custom- house examinations and the regulations as to the exportation of antiquities, special au- thorisation for this being required, and an assessment of the value for export duty being necessary also. Another item of interest is the advice given in the matter of suitable dress for tourists, which is a matter of real im- portance to Visitors to Egypt. Valuable hints are also given as to the medicines it is ad- visable to provide in case of attacks from the maladies which are prevalent in Egypt, such as fever, diarrhea, dysentery, etc. We do not think that any information likely to be required by the tourist is omitted from this very complete and interesting guide-book.

div.head: CARLTON, HOTEL.
div.p: Bulkily (near Alexandria)
RAMLEH”S FASHIONABLE HOTEL
Patronized by the elite.
Full Pension from P.T.

div.head: JOSEPH COMAS,
TECHNICAL ENGINEER.
div.p: Surveyor and Contractor in shipping. Takes
charge of Engines and Boilers. Undertakes
repairs of same, guaranteeing success. First
class references. Address: Rue EL Warsha
Maison Gabriel, ALEXANDRIA

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: New Silver Coins.
The Ministry of Finance has received from England 54 cases of new silver coins for cir- culation.
Abbassi Madhouse.
The Public Health Department has opened a credit of L.E. 10,000 for enlarging the mad- house at Abbassieh.
Amateur Theatricals.
The Ernesto Rossi dramatic society will give a performance at the Eden Theatre on Satur- day next of Giacosa’s 3-act comedy Tristi Amori.
Quarantine.
Vessels arriving in Turkish ports from Mo- kalla without pilgrims undergo five days quarantine and disinfection; those with pil- grims ten days.
Luxor-Assouan Line.
A contemporary states that it has been decided to widen the Luxor-Assouan line so that it should be the same as the normal Egyptian gauge.
Fall from a Roof.
A native boy fell from the roof of a house in the Attarin quarter yesterday and sustained very serious injuries. He lies in hospital in a precarious condition.
The Khanka Asylum.
In consequence of the decision of the Public Health Department to found a lunatic asylum at Khanka a railway line from Marg to Khanka will probably be opened.
Behram.
On the occasion of the celebration of the feast of Behram, his Excellency the Sirdar has approved of the free extra issue of 35 dirhams of meat per man to all Egyptian troops.
Suez Canal.
Ten vessels passed through the Canal on the 19th inst., of which 6 were British, 2 German, 1 French, 1 Dutch. The total receipts from the 1st to the 19th inst. were firs. 6,467,455.93.
British Consular Court.
The case of Leopold Camilleri, who is charg- ed with smuggling hashish by the Customs Administration, will be heard on Monday before the British Consular Court, Alexandria. “Our Sudan.”
The demand for Mr. John Ward’s work on the Sudan has been so large that a new edition has been rendered necessary. This edition contains a fine urological map of the whole Nile basin.
Fire in Cario.

A fire broke out on Tuesday evening in the house of a jeweller named Boutros Sahib at El Kobe’s. The Cario Fire Brigade succeeded in extinguishing the flames after an hour’s hard work. The damage is estimated at L.E. 1,000.
The Reward of Virtue.

An ingenious waiter at the Cafe d’ Alexan- aria, Cario, who attempted to make money by changing the 6’s and 9’s on lottery tickets to coughs, and thus imitate the winning num- bets, has been rewarded for his pains by 14 months’ imprisionment.
Charity Performance.

A charity performance under the patronage of M. de la Bouliniere will shortly be held at the College des Freres, Cario, on behalf of the poor pupils of the free schools. We are pro- missed an original play in verse which is said to be admirably written.
Egyptian Money Market.

Messier. H. de Vries and Boutiuny, stock and share brokers, Cario, publish a very detailed circular daily on the business of the stock market. This circular, which contains also a great deal of financial information, is sent gratis on application. [Advt.]
The Pisano Case.

Owing to the indisposition of Judge Cator, the trial of the Maltese Pisano, who wounded his mistress Victoria Dahan and then attempt- ed suicide, has been postponed, and the trial will very probably take place next week at H.B. M.’s Consulate, Cario.
A. L. M. & D. S.

The prospects of the Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society’s season are of the best. We understand that there is a likelihood of a dramatic performance being given next month, and that rehearsals of His Excellency the Governor will shortly be commenced, for production in the month of February next.
SPEND YOUR BEYRAM holidays at the Mena House Hotel. Moderate Terms. [Advt.]

div.head: THE BIBBY LINE.
div.p: The managers of the Bibby Line inform us that they have made an important improvement in the sailings of their homeward steamers, which is to come into force during the busy season, and which should prove of great convenience to passengers traveling by this popular line. Commencing with the S.S. Cheshire on March 4, and until the sailing of the same ship on June 10, it has been arranged for the steamers to leave Port Said at a fixed and regular time. They are, therefore, intended to sail as soon as passengers and luggage are embarked after the arrival of the train on Sunday due at Port Said at 3:30 pm.

The advantage obtained by this alteration is that the steamers will now arrive in Marseil- les in time for passengers to connect with the evening train on Friday for Paris, and so arrive in London on Saturday instead of Sunday as heretofore.

div.head: ROYALTY AT ALEXANDRIA.
PROBABLE VISIT OF RENOWN.
div.p: It has been proposed that, if arrangements can be made, the Prince of Wales should stop at Suakin on his way back from India in the spring, and proceed by the new railway to Khartoum, from which place he will journey to Cario, rejoining H.M.S. Renown at Alex- andria.

div.head: STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: His Excellency the Minister of Public Works, on the nomination of the Railway Board, has today appointed Major L’Es- strange Johnstone, R.E., to be General Manager of the State Railways.

div.head: MINISTRY OF THH,JN,T£RIOR.
div.p: Mr. J.F. Wells, Inspector of Mines, Ministry of Finance, and Mr. R.H. Greaves, Assistant Inspector of Mines, have been granted the status of inspector of theMinistry of the lnterior and will deal direct with the Adviser, and with Moudirs, on all matters concerning the Bedouin tribes in the desert and in the moudiriehs of Upper Egypt.

div.head: PUBLIC HEALTH DEPT.
div.p: The jurisdictions of the inspectors of the Public Health Department have been rearran- ged as follows: Menoufieh and Behera, Mr. Burnett Stuart; Gharbieh and Dakahlieh, Mr. Dallin; Charkieh and Fayoum, Mr. Haines; Beni Soueif and Minieh, Mr. Paterson; Assiout and Ghirgeh, Mr. McKillop; Kalioubieh and Ghirgeh, Mohhamed Effendi Musa; Keneh and Assouas, Mohamed Effendi Husni Yaghen.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive visited his lamailieh properties on Tuesday and returned to Koubbeh last night. His Highness received the ministers this morning and will take part in the religious ceremony of the Leilat el Kadr at the Citadel mosque this evening.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Judge Cator is indisposed and has been cosequently unable to proceed to Cairo to open the session of the Supreme Consular Court there. As soon as he has recovered be will go to Cairo and will afterwards return to Alexandria to take the cases down for hearing at the Supreme Court here.
There are three criminal cases awaiting hearing before the Supreme Court here

Rex v. Salvatore Camilleri, who is charged with being an accessory in the shooting of a certain Panel's by one Tissandrello, and also with aiding the latter to escape from custody. Salvatore Camilleri was a member of the Alexandria City Police force.
Rex v. Moses Carasso, who is charged with stabbing and wounding Marco Levi Carasso.

Rex v. Gerasimo Agius. The accused, it will be remembered, caused considerable excite- ment at Alexandria in the summer by running amuck and subsequently trying to commit suicide. He is charged with wounding Pietro Dagriano with intent to murder him, and also with wounding four other men.

div.head: AMERICAN CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: This morning the case was heard, at the American Consular Agency at Alexandria, of the United States Government v. Leuty. The defendant is an American dentist practising at Alexandria and was accused of going about with concealed firearms and threatening to shoot with a revolver. The case was heard by the Hon. Mr. Iddings, American Diplomatic Agent and Consul General. Leuty was bound over to keep the peace and enter into a bond for $200, to pay a fine of $10, and to pay all the costs of the case.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING OPERATIONS.
div.p: A cablegram from the Um Rus gold mine gives the following return of the operations daring October:- 680 tons of ore crushed; 398 ozs of bar gold were produced, valued at £1,340. 510 tons of tailings have been stored of an average away value of 3 dots per ton. The mill ran 22 days of 24 hours.

div.head: AUTOMOBILE CLUB.
div.p: A circular has been issued to a number of motor-car owners at Alexandria, at the instance of H. H. Prince Aziz, inviting them to attend a meeting to be held at the Mc- hamed Aly Club this evening at 6 o’clock with a view to putting the local branch of tho Automobile Club d’Egypte on a sound footing.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Dumbes arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday.
The Moss liner Amasis arrived this morn- ing from Barry with cargo of coal.

div.head: THE SCURRIES CASE.
SENSATIONAL DISCLOSURES.
(BY TELEPHONE.)
div.p: We understand that on the conclusion of the hearing of the action brought by M. Pou- trel against the Hon. A. J. Davey, for wrong- fun dismissal, a packet of letters bearing upon the case was handed to Maitre Carton de Wait. These letters are of the utmost import- once, providing as they do, that a complete sys- tim of concealment had been organized by M. Pouter and the late M. de la Bouglise and others, at the expense of Hon. A. J. Davey and several of his colleagues.

We are informed that a letter in this con- nection, written by M. Poutrel, contained full instructions as to the use of a private code which was to be employed in combination with the ordinary code of the Scurries Company.

Another letter written by the late M. de la Bouglise, contained instructions to the effect that ordinary matters of business were to be left in the hands of the Hon. A. J. Davey, in the hope that he would imagine himself au courant with everything and ask no questions. Important and confidential matters, such as drafts, acceptances, etc., were to be kept strictly from his notice.

Under these circumstances we imagine it will be difficult for the most ardent supporters of M. Poutrel to contend that his dismissal was unjustifiable. We understand that copies of these letters have been submitted to the Court, and to Me. Guilhaumou, counsel for M. Poutrel.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: The Quarantine Board has decided not to make any further mention on the bills of health issued in Egyptian ports of the ex- istence in Egypt of bovine typhus.

div.head: TELEPHONE CO. OF EGYPT.
div.p: Great improvements in the service of the Telephone Company, both at Cairo and Alex- andria, are now being carried out with a view to the ultimate displacement, so far at least as the main thoroughfares are concerned, of the present system of overhead wires. Under- ground cables are being laid, and some of these consist of as many as 672 wires, these dimi- nishing in number as they are distant from the centre of the town. The work will take some months to complete, as the total length of the cables is very great.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CONSERVATOIRE.
div.p: We are requested by the committee of the Alexandria Conservatoire to publish the follow- ing note:—

"We are glad to be able to announce that an appeal to the Government on behalf of our society has met with a favorable response, and a donation of L.E. 200 has been promised to meet immediate needs. Moreover, the Financial Adviser authorises us to state that he is will- ing to recommend an annual State subvention of L.E. 100 (which is the amount of the Mani cipal subvention for 1905) on condition that the appeal which he understands is about to be made to the public of Alexandria for sus- criptions, meets with adequate response.

"As long as Alexandrians are willing, to support the society, the Government will be willing to lend a helping hand, but the Government subvention if contingent on the collection of an adequate amount from the local public.
"In the opinion of the Adviser the L.E. 50 or L.E. 60 at present collected does not by any means constitute an ‘adequate amount’."

div.head: CONCERT AT BOULAC.
div.p: The opening concert of the season at the well-appointed Railway Institute at Boulac took place last Saturday evening. There was a large attendance of members and friends, many of whom had to remain on the balcony, the concert-room being crowded. A capital programme had been got together and was ably sustained by a company of talented and popular artistes. The concert opened by a pianoforte solo by Miss Bingham, after which followed two fine violin solos by Mr. Ed. Gahar, who rendered these in a very effective manner. Band man Smith at once become a favorite with his song, "Under the Deodeh,” and had to respond to an encore. In the second part he gave the "Bes,” and again responding to an encore, gave in characteristic style “imita- tions,” which was received by the audience with round after round of applause. Colour Sergt. Harrington was heard to advantage in his songs “Big Ben” and “Fight of Ages,” followed by Lce. Corp. Glynn, who gave a capital render- ing of “Moonbeams”. Miss Bingham gave in an able manner another solo, and later a duet with Miss Strachan, which was well received. Gramaphone selections were given by Mr. Richard Curtis and were well received by the audience. Bandsman Gibbons as ac- companist left nothing to be desired. The thanks of the members are due to the popular chairman, Mr. G. Walker, and an able sub- committee, of which Mr. Isop is convener, in providing such a pleasant evening’s enter- tainment.

div.head: EGYPTIAN IVORY.
div.p: Egyptian ivory to the amount of 7 tons 15 owt. has arrived in London for the quarter- ly sales, which will be held in January. The total quantity of ivory which has arrived from all sources is over 18 tons.

div.head: A BRAZILIAN MISSION.
STUDYING THE ASSOUAN DAM.
div.p: Dr. Th. Nascimento and M. C. du Pin Y. Almeida have been sent to the East by the Brazilian Government to study all agricultural questions that are of interest and importance to the great South American Republic, and especially irrigation and sugar planting. We hear that they propose to visit the principal British and Dutch possessions in the East, and will also study irrigation in Holland. They have been received by Lord Cromer, have interviewed Sir William Willcocks and Mr. Fosden, and are now in Upper Egypt studying sugar and the Assouan Dam.

div.head: RIFLE BRIGADE’S DEPARTURE.
div.p: The 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade’s departure will be widely regretted at Cario. The regi- meant was popular and efficient, alike socially and professionally, and its distinguished record was upheld during its stay in Cario. Brig- Gen. Bullock’s tribute to the battalion was thoroughly well deserved and we need not say that Rifles had a capital send off on Tuesday evening, when they entrained for Suez, where they have embarked in the troop- ship Assaye for Bombay from where the battalion will rail to its new station, Chan- battia.

The 2nd Battalion of the “Green Jackets” served in the Khartoum Expedition, 1898 includ- ing the battle of Omdurman, and subsequently was in Ladysmith, throughout the siege and gallant defense helping to “keep the old flag flying,” After the war it went to Cario and then Khartoum. It was last in India from 1857 to 1868.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: A banquet was given at the Khedivial Club last night by H.E. Mahmoud Pasha Sidey, Governor of Alexandria in honor of Baron von Humboldt Lachroeden, German Consul at Alexandria, on the occasion of his appointment to the post of German Consul General at Cape Town. The guests included Baron and Baroness Action, Hekekian Pasha and Mme Hekekian, Miralai and the Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson, Mr. Hellwig, Judge and Mme Gescher, Mr. and Mrs. Planta, Mr. and Mrs. von Tschudi, Mr. Scotidis, Mr. and Mrs. Rothacker.

Mr. Iddings, American Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, has arrived from Cario to sit as judge in several matters now pending at the consular agency here. He is accompanied by Mrs. Iddings and both are the guests or Judge Batcheller at his villa in Ramleh.
Count Arrivabene Gonzaga leaves today to take up his new post at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs at Rome.

Mirza Faraj Allah Khan, who is expected to be one of our visitors this winter, is watching events in the Caucasus for the Persian Government, and has recently been decorated with the 1st class of the Liou and San.
Sir Elwin Palmer left Cario on Tuesday night to meet Lady Palmer, who arrived by the Worcestershire at Port Said.

Among those who are leaving London for Egypt within the next few days are Sir Henry and Lady Stephen, General Inigo Jones, Lady Cantaloupe, the Dowager Lady Donoughmore and Lady Norah Holy Hutchinson and Sir T. and Lady Fryer. Mr. Claude Loather, M.P. who has been ordered to Egypt by his medical advisor, will also leave shortly.
Mr. Mack, a director of the Egyptian Laud and General Trust, has arrived at Cario.
Baron and Baroness Felix Menasce and their children leave today for Mena House Hotel, where they intend to stay about a fortnight.
Leave of absence for one month, on private affairs, has been granted to Milhe’m Bey Shakir, Inspector Recruiting Department.
We are sorry to hear that Dr. Baker, Sanitary Inspector of the Suez Canal district, has been obliged to retire for reasons of health.

Leave of absence, on private affairs has been granted to Khalil Gamal El Dia Bey. Moodier of Keneh for 12 days, Mohamed Ali Sharara Bey, Moudir of Fatoum, for 1 month, and Mohamed Islam Bey, Governor of El Arish, for 3 months.

Major C. L. E. Robertson Eustace, D. S. O., 1st Bn, K. R. R. Corps is coming from Crete to Egypt, to join the headquarters of his battalion for duty on being relieved at Crete by Major R. S. Oxley, of the same Corps, who is joining from India.

div.head: Beck & Co’s Pilsener Beer.
BREMEN.
div.p: Obtainable from every Respectable Firm
IN CARIO, ALEXANDRIA AND THE SUDAN.
Otherwise apply to
E. J. FLEURENT
F. MICALLEF

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
COUR D’APPEL MIXTE
Un point de Droit
div.p: Il s’agi sait de savior si lenterd action du code d’instruction criminale de donner des pieces de l’rustruction écrite et de l’inter- rogatiore du prévenue a’appliquait seulement a l’audience on si elle s’etedait in dehors aux juges memes our les empêcher de puiser les elements de leur conviction dans les dits inter- rogatiore et instruction.

Dans une affaire ministère public contre Ibrahim Emara et Ibrahim Brian, la cour d’ap- per mixte, se basant sur le printe pe que la loi avait en pour but de protéger l’insulte et que cette protection cut été illusoire sans l’in- terdiction pour le juge de puiser sa conviction dans l’interrogatoire et l’instruction en ques- ion, vient d’annuler un jugement pronounce a Mansourah, parce que le tribunal de cette ville a’ était fonde sur leurs declarations pour con- damner les inculpes.
La Cour a donc renvoyé l’affaire devant le meme tribunal correctionnel de Mansourah pour y être statue de nouveau par d’antres juges.

div.head: L’encombrement des Quais.
div.p: On se rappelle les embarras et difficultés de débarquement ris marchandise an port d’ Alex- andria an conta de l’annue 1904.
C’est dans ces circumstances qu’un délai de 20 jours a partir de d’arrivée du Fos fut stipules pour son déchargement.

Ce delai ayant été dépassé par les destins- tires un procès fit engage par devant le tri- bunsl de commerce d’ALexandria gui, estimant que la stipulation du délai de 20 jours laissait virtuellement aux risques des destinataires “The Commercial Estates Co. of Egypt” les retards éventuels du déchargement, decide que le capitaine avait droit d’être indemnise pour le chômage de son navire dans le port d’Alex- andria et condamna les destinataires a lul payer une somme adequate.
La Cour d’Appel Misote devant laquelle appeal avait été interjeté parla Commercial Eststed vient de confirmer le jugement de prem ere instance et de condamner la société appelanteaux dépens.

div.head: COUR D’APPEL DE PARIS.
LES HOIRS NEGRELLIO LA. CIE DU CANAL
div.p: C’est une affaire très grave et pleine de difficultes que celle qui est sourire, en ce mo- ment, a la premiere chambre de la Cour, presi- dee par M. le sénateur premier president Emile Forichon.

Il s’agit de l’admission d’une requête civile tendant a la retraction, par la Cour, d’un de ses arrêts, tenu le 22 mai 1896, au profit de M. de Lessers et de la Compagnie Maritime de Suez contre les héritiers de M. le chevalier Alora de Negrelli-Medelbr, ancien membre de la Commission supérieure d’etudes pour le percement du canal. C’est sa fille, Mme veuve Gris, nee Merie de Negrelli qui, par son ener- aie, est arrivée a deteminer les revenictioned novellas des héritiers de l’illustre défunt.

Ce procès evoque l’bietuire a la fois gran diose et douloureuse du percenient de l’isthme de Suez. Il nous montre comment les hommes, après s’être élèves juequ au sommet des gran- deure, peuvent être précipités dans l’abime, et fait revivre des souvenirs qu’on pouvait croire a jamais disparue. Il semble, su effet, que les demandeurs soient determines a lever bien des voiles et a démasquer certains agissementes, restes juequ’a present ignores, dont la cennais- sance pourrait provoquer quelque scandale.

Aussi le public, avids de ces questions mystérieuses june uu peu de l’henneur des homme, su presse tel nombreux pour ecouter les orateurs qui vont se livrer, devant la chambre la plus élevée de la Cour, a un brillant tournoi.

Du cote des reclamanits, c’est Me Maurice Tezenas l’avocat elegant et fin diseur, dont le trait juste va frapper l’adversaire au point sensible C’est Me Chenn le nouvesr baton- nier le altre du jeune Palais, a la parole acérés et incisive dont l’esprit railleur s’ex- prime en uno language chats due sert un organe mordant et sonore a la fois. De l’antres cote de la barre, c’est Me Barboux, le repre- sentant de l’école ancienne, l’avocat classique, dont la verte vieillesse apporté, chaque jour, avec une vigueur nouvelle le poids des causes les plus lourdes.
Essayous, en nous inspirant de la plaidoirie de ces maîtres, de retracer la des est du procès.

Le les octobre 1858, mourait a Vienne a l’age de soixante ans, le chevalier de Nagrelli conseiller imperial et royal, ingénieur, directeur des travaux publics, inspecteur general des chemins de fer autrichiens.

Sa veuve n’ignorait pas qu’il avait joue un role decisif hans l’entreprise du canal de Suez. qu’il avait fait partie de la premiere. Suciete d’etudes constituesra Paris, en 1846, per les Saint Simoniens, qu’il avait été la obeville ouvre été détoures les négociations diplomati- ques, financières et qu’il avait gardejurqri sa mort la confidence du gouvernement autrichien et du vice-roi d’Egypte. Elle avait que, pen- dans vingt ans, son mari s’était concilie l’estime et l’affection de M. de Lessene auquel de Negrelli design, comme agent financier de l’entreprise, un propre ami de la famille, Revoltella, banquier a Trieste et futur vice- president de la Commannie de Suez.
Mais elle ne connaitrait pas les droits qu’il avait pu acquérir ignorante des affairs sa douleur et l’amitié de M. de Lessena manu. coherent tout conn con de naitre en son reprit.
Cependant, au lendemain de la
